intro: Pseudoselago violacea, commonly known as the violetleaf pseudoselago, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, violet-blue flowers. The plant typically grows in acidic, well-drained soils and thrives in partial to full shade. Its leaves are lance-shaped and glossy, while its flowers bloom in clusters, adding ornamental value to woodland gardens. Pseudoselago violacea is often used in horticulture for its aesthetic appeal and ability to thrive in shaded environments.
